list_page_teaser: The detectives on The Wire are a fairly diverse group, and their personalities are quite different from the temperaments of most of the officers working in the detail.  Click to learn more!
description_html:
These portraits of the personalities of McNulty and Freamon show how both of them prefer ideas to facts. McNulty's image shows he's more outgoing and logical, while Freamon's portrait shows he's a bit more emotional than Jimmy.

Meanwhile, Bunk's portrait shows he's more emtional and pragmatic than McNulty, while Landsman's image shows he has strong tendencies for being logical, decisive, and realistic — qualities his bosses show, all the way up the chain of command to the mayor.

image_list.title: Jimmy McNulty
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: The Blue in Jimmy McNulty's spiritual portrait shows he is open to new ideas, and the Green shows is rational.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents McNulty's dominant personality trait, iNtuition: idealism and hope for the future; openness to ideas; very slight/moderate/strong preference for ideas over facts.

The Blue in McNulty's spiritual portrait represents their dominant personality trait, their very slight/moderate/strong preference for seeing the world more in terms of ideas than of facts; need for intellectual stimulation.
image_list.explain_dom_constant: In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  He/She demonstrates/exhibits this trait in their (note that is easier to find examples of decisions than perceptions!) ....
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents McNulty's auxiliary personality trait, Thinking: objectivity; rationality; cool-headedness; very slight/moderate/strong preference for logic/reason/objectivity over emotion/empathy/subjectivity; their very slight/moderate/strong preference for the logical/rational/objective over the emotional/personal/subjective.

The Green in McNulty's spiritual portrait represents their auxiliary personality trait, their very slight/moderate/strong preference for making logical/rational/subjective rather than emotional/personal/objective decisions; their very slight/moderate/strong preference for being emotional/personal/subjective rather than logical/impersonal/objective.
image_list.explain_aux_constant: In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  He/She demonstrates/exhibits this trait in their (note that is easier to find examples of decisions than perceptions!) ....
image_list.story_html_img: Idea: only include images with stories for family and friends.

image_list.title: Bunk Moreland
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: The Yellow in Bunk Moreland's spiritual portrait shows he is open to new experiences, and the Red shows he is friendly.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Bunk's dominant personality trait, Sensing: pragmatism; pragmatic; practical; realism; realistic; outlook; openness to experiences; very slight/moderate/strong preference for facts over ideas.

The Yellow in Bunk's spiritual portrait represents their dominant personality trait, their very slight/moderate/strong preference for seeing the world more in terms of facts than of ideas; need for sensual stimulation.
image_list.explain_dom_constant: In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  He/She demonstrates/exhibits this trait in their (note that is easier to find examples of decisions than perceptions!) ....
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Bunk's auxiliary personality trait, Feeling: passion; amiability; friendliness; compassion; warmth; very slight/moderate/strong preference for emotion/empathy/subjectivity over logic/reason/objectivity; their very slight/moderate/strong preference for the emotional/personal/subjective over the logical/rational/objective.

The Red in Bunk's spiritual portrait represents their auxiliary personality trait, their very slight/moderate/strong preference for making emotional/personal/objective rather than logical/rational/subjective decisions; their very slight/moderate/strong preference for being emotional/personal/subjective rather than logical/impersonal/objective.
image_list.explain_aux_constant: In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  He/She demonstrates/exhibits this trait in their (note that is easier to find examples of decisions than perceptions!) ....
image_list.story_html_img: Idea: only include images with stories for family and friends.

image_list.title: Lester Freamon
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: The Blue in Lester Freamon's spiritual portrait shows he is more comfortable with ideas than facts, and the Red shows he can be warm and friendly.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Freamon's dominant personality trait, Feeling: passion; amiability; friendliness; compassion; warmth; very slight/moderate/strong preference for emotion/empathy/subjectivity over logic/reason/objectivity; their very slight/moderate/strong preference for the emotional/personal/subjective over the logical/rational/objective.

The Red in Freamon's spiritual portrait represents their dominant personality trait, their very slight/moderate/strong preference for making emotional/personal/objective rather than logical/rational/objective decisions; their very slight/moderate/strong preference for being emotional/personal/subjective rather than logical/impersonal/objective.
